#Text=A typical passenger conveyor, such as an escalator or moving walk, includes a truss, a plurality of sequentially connected treadplates traveling through a closed loop path within the truss, and a machine for driving the treadplates.
#Text=A control system is used to control the operation of the conveyor for such parameters as speed and direction.
#Text=Such conveyors are a very efficient means to move large numbers of passengers between floors or locations.
#Text=In modem conveyors, the control systems have become increasingly complex in an effort to improve efficiency and reduce wear and cost of operation.
#Text=One such control system incorporates a sensor to detect passengers entering the conveyor.
#Text=Upon detection of a passenger, the conveyor is switched on and the treadplates begin moving.
#Text=After the passenger exits the conveyor, the conveyor is switched off.
#Text=This type of control system saves energy by not running continuously during no-load conditions.
#Text=A drawback to this system, however, is the generation of peak loads during the frequent switching on and off of the conveyor.
#Text=One disclosed solution to this problem is to use a variable frequency converter to control the operation of the conveyor.
#Text=An example of this type of controller is disclosed in U.S.
#Text=Pat.
#Text=No. 4,748,394, entitled "Control Apparatus for Escalator" and issued to Watanabe.
#Text=This patent discloses an escalator operating at two speeds.
#Text=At low speed, the motor is controlled by the frequency conversion means to operate at the low speed until a passenger is detected.
#Text=Upon detection, the frequency is gradually raised until there is synchronization between the current generated from the frequency conversion means and the power source.
#Text=At that point, the motor is switched to the power source.
#Text=A similar concept is proposed in published German Patent Application No. 4,313,424 A1.
#Text=While this solution may provide some benefits, even when operated at a reduced speed wear of the escalator components still occurs and energy is wasted during no-load conditions.

#Text=The above art notwithstanding, scientists and engineers under the direction of Applicant's Assignee are working to develop drives and control systems for passenger conveyors that improve efficiency and minimize wear.
